key_points: One of the world's largest container ships, Ever Given, partially refloated in the Suez Canal.
The Ever Given ran aground due to loss of steering capability amid high winds and a dust storm.
Eight tugboats were deployed to free the vessel, which blocks a crucial lane in the canal.
The blockage affected Asia-Europe trade, with about 50 ships a day passing through the canal in 2019.
The ship's technical manager, Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement, confirmed that all crew were safe.
A growing number of tankers, carrying millions of barrels of crude oil, were waiting to pass through.
Strong winds may have caused the incident, turning the containers into a vast sail.
Human error and the necessity of not delaying shipments might have contributed to the accident.
The Suez Canal's importance as an international trade artery was highlighted.
Previous incidents in the canal include a Japanese ship in 2017 and the CSCL Indian Ocean near Hamburg in 2016.
spokespersons: Jamil Sayegh (former captain and maritime law specialist)
